author: Sefy Levy
description: Classify pXRF/XRF measurements based on relative standard deviation (RSD) following accepted QA/QC practice
reference: Potts & West (2008); USGS pXRF QA/QC guidelines; NIST uncertainty framework

classifications.name: HIGH PRECISION (RSD < 10%)
classifications.description: Excellent analytical precision; suitable for quantitative and publication-grade work

rules.comment: Typical threshold for high-confidence pXRF precision on mid-Z elements

classifications.notes: Comparable to laboratory-grade repeatability for well-behaved elements

classifications.name: ACCEPTABLE PRECISION (10â€“20%)
classifications.description: Good field precision; suitable for semi-quantitative interpretation and geochemical screening

rules.comment: Commonly accepted range for field-grade pXRF precision

classifications.notes: Appropriate for geometallurgy, mapping, and provenance triage

classifications.name: LOW PRECISION (20â€“30%)
classifications.description: Moderate uncertainty; usable for qualitative trends but not reliable for quantitative interpretation

rules.comment: Often associated with low concentrations or matrix effects

classifications.notes: Use cautiously; verify critical samples with lab analysis

classifications.name: UNRELIABLE (RSD > 30%)
classifications.description: High uncertainty; not suitable for quantitative or semi-quantitative interpretation

rules.comment: Indicates poor precision; typically requires re-measurement

classifications.name: NO ERROR DATA
classifications.description: Uncertainty values missing; cannot compute RSD
classifications.notes: Error data required for precision assessment

notes: RSD = error/value. Thresholds reflect widely used pXRF QA/QC practice: <10% high precision, 10â€“20% acceptable, 20â€“30% low precision, >30% unreliable. Suitable for mid-Z elements such as Zr.
